title: Bank of Canada Governor Stresses the Limitations of Rate Estimates
summary: Stephen Poloz is concerned markets attach too much importance to the precise numbers in estimated neutral range. WASHINGTON-Estimates of Canada's neutral interest rate are meant to provide a sense of where monetary policy could end up and shouldn't be seen as a near-term target, Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz said Saturday.

title: Mnuchin Says Trade Talks Near Final Round
summary: Treasury secretary says U.S. officials will speak to Chinese counterparts in coming week on a narrowing set of issues. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Saturday the U.S. and China are continuing to make progress on trade talks and "getting close to the final round of concluding issues."

title: Democrat Sets Final Deadline for Trump Tax Returns
summary: Rep. Richard Neal called the law 'unambiguous' that the returns must be handed over; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin called the new deadline 'arbitrary'. WASHINGTON-House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Rep. Richard Neal set a final April 23 deadline for the IRS to turn over President Trump's tax returns.

title: Orioles' Chris Davis Hits His Way Out of Dismal Streak
summary: First baseman lines a two-run single against Boston to end record hitless streak for a position player at 54 straight at-bats. BOSTON-Baltimore Orioles' Chris Davis ended his streak of futility in his first at-bat on Saturday when he lined a bases-loaded, two-run single to right in the first inning against the Boston Red Sox.

title: Facebook and Google Get an Unusual Crew of Allies in Europe
summary: Nativist parties join in with left-wing groups and others to protest against tighter regulation of U.S. tech platforms. U.S. internet giants fighting regulatory pressure in Europe have gained support from an array of political forces that would ordinarily battle each other.

title: David Hare on Rudolf Nureyev's 'Rebellious Streak'
summary: David Hare, who wrote the screenplay for 'The White Crow,' Ralph Fiennes's film about Rudolf Nureyev, talks about the Russian dancer and defector's extraordinary life. Dance and politics become intertwined in David Hare's screenplay for "The White Crow," a movie about Russian ballet dancer Rudolf Nureyev's decision to defect to the West in 1961.

title: As Measles Spreads, Schools Turn Away Unvaccinated Students
summary: In Kentucky, bans on students without shots spark lawsuit. Some school districts in the U.S. are booting unvaccinated students from campuses where infectious-disease cases have been confirmed, as the spread of measles accelerates in some states.

title: Indictment Marks Dramatic Turn for Well-Connected Democratic Attorney
summary: Greg Craig was counselor to Presidents Clinton and Obama and was involved in high-profile legal cases before getting caught up in the Mueller probe. WASHINGTON-The indictment of former Obama White House counsel Greg Craig on charges related to foreign work marks a stunning turn in a legal career that has spanned decades and drew shocked responses from his former law partners and colleagues.

title: Trans-Pacific Trade Party Is Raging on Without the U.S.
summary: American beef exporters may be the first to feel the squeeze of the Asian agreement on tariffs. Much of the American interest in the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade deal bridging economies in the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions, dried up after the U.S. backed out in 2016. Now the bloc is about to become a headache for it.

title: Everyone's Familiar With Facebook; Not Everyone Still Cares
summary: News coverage of its handling of client data has been high, yet the company is outpacing peers in stock performance. If you think news about Facebook is crowding your feed, you're right. But that isn't new news.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Touts Red Carpet Treatment for VIPs
summary: Exclusive $25,000 tickets draw deep-pocketed cinephiles, criticism that 'it's more about being ritzy' than movies. The Tribeca Film Festival started under the most humbling of circumstances, as a way to bring new life to lower Manhattan in the aftermath of 9/11.

title: North Korea's Kim Gives U.S. End-of-Year Deadline on Nuclear Talks
summary: Leader says he remains open to a third summit with President Trump, with whom he says he has good personal relations. SEOUL-North Korean leader Kim Jong Un gave the U.S. until the year's end to break a deadlock in stalled nuclear talks, Pyongyang state media reported on Saturday, saying he remained open to a third summit with President Trump.

title: Burned Out at Work? Here's How to Find Your Passion-Or Get It Back
summary: Follow your passion? It's not so easy. Experts say small steps, not dramatic leaps, create the best path.. From the time Freeman Wood was 5 years old, he wanted to be an explorer. He dreamed of climbing mountains, trekking through deserts, mapping some uncharted terrain.

title: Baby Boomers and the Art of Parenting Adult Kids
summary: More involved with grown children than previous generations, many boomers struggle with letting them go.

title: Legal Pot Sales Are Off to Slow Start in Canada
summary: Recreational sales of marijuana are muted, hurt by supply constraints and competition from the black market. TORONTO-Canada's experiment with legal pot is off to a slow and sputtering start.

title: Even at 80, This Boss Sets the Pace at Work
summary: A Pennsylvania car dealer makes fitness challenges for himself and his employees that are anything but easy; 125 push-ups, anyone?. Most people celebrate birthdays with cake. Fred Beans recently celebrated his 80th birthday by knocking out 125 push-ups. The annual challenge, which he started eight years ago, motivates him to keep fit throughout the year.

title: 'Snap+Share: Transmitting Photographs From Mail Art to Social Networks' Review: Images That Say 'Wish You Were Here'
summary: An exhibition looks at the many ways people have shared images across history, from photo-based illustrated postcards to the latest apps.. San Francisco

title: WhatsApp Users Spread Antivaccine Rumors in India
summary: Many of the same reports that have misled Americans are spreading on WhatsApp in India, where some vaccination programs have been halted. NEW DELHI-Antivaccine misinformation, some of it from social media posts in the West, is spreading in India on WhatsApp, undermining efforts to root out measles and rubella in a country where tens of thousands of people are struck by the diseases each year.

title: Beware the Bold Claims of Tax-Loss Harvesting
summary: Critics of the investment strategy say tax situations often are more complicated and the benefits can be overstated. The exchange-traded fund industry has claimed credit for democratizing strategies once available only to the rich, such as trading oil futures or using leverage to amplify returns. The latest target: your tax bill.

title: Hollywood Action: Writers to Fire Agents Over Fee Deadlock
summary: The war over words centers on agencies engaging in activities that writers allege are a conflict of interest. The Writers Guild of America late Friday told its 15,000-strong membership of television and movie writers to fire their agents after it was unable to convince the majority of Hollywood's talent agencies to halt practices the union alleges are unethical and illegal.

title: Where Washington, D.C's Elites Sleep
summary: In Great Falls, Va., mansions are big and price tags are even bigger.. The Washington, D.C., area is known for its transiency, which is what makes Great Falls, Va., stand out. About 20 miles northwest of the White House and situated along the Potomac River, the roughly 25-square-mile community is close-knit. With its first land grant given out in 1709, Great Falls's rural heritage is apparent in its old-timey village center and residences-horse farms, Tudor mansions and Craftsman houses on unusually expansive acreage for the D.C. region. With a population of about 15,500 and a median household income of $230,450, according to census data, Great Falls is mix of Beltway power brokers and Dulles tech-corridor workers who want to live an idyllic, country lifestyle outside of the spotlight.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How Once-Tiny Tyrannosaurs Became Titans
summary: Recent finds show that ancestors of T. rex were diminutive for eons. The evolutionary puzzle is how they grew up so fast.. At a length of over 40 feet and weighing nine tons, Tyrannosaurus rex was the largest predator ever to stalk the Earth-and we revel in its fearsomeness. No dinosaur has been studied more exhaustively: Paleontologists have investigated its eyesight, hearing, speed, digestion and bite force, to say nothing of what those tiny, dangling two-tined arms might have been good for. In pop culture, the mighty carnivore has become a fixture of prehistoric tales, where, somehow or another, it always ends up dining on a few hapless humans.

title: Big Brother at the Mall
summary: The privacy debate moves beyond e-commerce as magic mirrors and beacons log shoppers' data in bricks-and-mortar stores. WASHINGTON-The battle to protect consumer data is moving from cyberspace to shopping malls, as Congress scrutinizes how advanced technology increasingly follows shoppers around bricks-and-mortar stores.

title: 'The Greek Freak': Milwaukee Bucks Star (and Informal Management Muse)
summary: Basketball executive Peter Feigin taps into the 6-foot-11 Giannis Antetokounmpo, a former U.S. senator and others for guidance in leading an NBA team. President, Milwaukee Bucks

title: Apple and Qualcomm's Billion-Dollar Staredown
summary: A frosty relationship between Tim Cook and Steve Mollenkopf has deepened a dispute between the companies. A meeting between Tim Cook and Steve Mollenkopf a year ago at Apple Inc.'s headquarters started with a tense moment.

title: Trump Revives Idea to Send Migrants to 'Sanctuary Cities'
summary: Previously discarded option of relocating detained migrants comes amid growing frustration with border. WASHINGTON-President Trump revived an idea of relocating detained immigrants to so-called sanctuary cities, signaling he is considering previously discarded options amid his growing frustration over the flow of Central American families seeking asylum at the southern U.S. border.

title: Tiger Woods Surges Into Contention at Masters
summary: The 14-time major winner shook off incident to close within one shot of lead. AUGUSTA, Ga.-In his remarkable comeback, Tiger Woods has overcome four back surgeries, the last of which left him wondering whether he would ever play again. But to climb into contention at the Masters on Friday, he had to overcome something even more improbable: an accidental takeout slide from a member of his own security detail.
